subsection.name: Configuration file format
subsection.p: If you prefer XML over Java you can create a configuration file with the following format:
subsection.source:
<aspect-repository> <aspect> <interface> com.tirsen.nanning.SideAspect </interface> <interceptor> com.tirsen.nanning.NullInterceptor </interceptor> <interceptor> com.tirsen.nanning.MockInterceptor </interceptor> <target> com.tirsen.nanning.SideAspectImpl </target> </aspect> <class> <interface> com.tirsen.nanning.Intf </interface> <interceptor> com.tirsen.nanning.MockInterceptor </interceptor> <interceptor> com.tirsen.nanning.NullInterceptor </interceptor> <target> com.tirsen.nanning.Impl </target>
<aspect interface="com.tirsen.nanning.SideAspect" /> </class> </aspect-repository>

Oh, forgot to mention... The configuration file is actually a Jelly-script, which means you can probably do all sorts of crazy things and probably also embed Nanning-aspects inside other Jelly-scripts. I haven't had time to test all the implications of this feature but I guess it's kind of cool. I guess this also breaks the "simplest thing that could possibly work"-design I usually prefer but codewise it was just slightly more or just as complex as parsing the XML by hand, mostly due to Jelly being designed so well.

subsection.name: Method filtering
subsection.p:
Preliminary method filtering has also been implemented. If your interceptor likes to filter out the methods that it will intercept implement
FilterMethodsInterceptor. If you return false to the call to
FilterMethodsInterceptor.interceptsMethod your interceptor will not be called for that method.
